pr_title: External data from links, interal refactoring

timeline.message: [#97] draft how link resolving could work
[#97] draft how link resolving could work

timeline.bodyText: @sl0815 still no time to work on this? The GitHub connection is already working. Loading Sonarqube stuff is just a matter of knowing their API.
timeline.author: bonndan

timeline.message: [#97] external links resolved earlier, now contribute to input DTOs
[#97] refactored resolving of templates (no more coupling with templates map between resolvers)
[#97] refactored indexer: distinction between Processor and Resolver

timeline.bodyText: Is this just a Map merge? If yes, why not use item.getLinks().putAll(increment.getLinks());
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: It is putIfAbsent 😄
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: ok
replies.author: mfbieber

timeline.bodyText: Shouldn't the method be named resolve()?
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: excellent observation, Sherlock!
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: done.
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText: Since this is all about resolvers and processors. What is the difference between both of them? They both operate on the provided LandscapeDescription input. Is the result a modified input which is later applied to the Landscape?
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: Maybe the naming can be discussed. Resolvers just modify and extended the input, but not not affect the final output.
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText:
Why is an input modified if it does not have an effect on the final output?
I am just trying to understand the underlying mechanism ;)
replies.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: First, the data is aggregated in the ComponentDescription objects. This is done sequentially by the different Resolvers. Then the processors do their work and start mapping the input to the final Landscape.
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: Okay thanks, now I understand!
replies.author: mfbieber

timeline.bodyText: The contains check is not necessary. Can't this also be simpler like this: item.getInterfaces().addAll(template.getInterfaces());?
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText: Why does this not extend Resolver?
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: You're right, I have changed it based on your previous comment.
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText: Do you use  an abstract class instead of an interface only because of the ProcessLog field?
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: Yes, so far. We can change it to an interface and add the processlog as further argument to process/resolve.
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: It's ok, I dont mind the abstract class. I think the only thing that "bothers" me is that I don't fully understand what the resolvers and the processors do and why - see comment above :)
replies.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: Until a few days ago I was not aware of that, too. I just observed that some of the classes in Indexer only worked on the input objects, while others only/mostly worked on the output.
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText: Why is the name set to null?
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: Because names are more or less unique and I think it makes no sense to apply the same name to different items.
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: Isn't the name then null by default for a template? Why set it explicitly?
replies.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText:
I mean, annotate it as @Nullable, make the getter either return @Nullable or  @nonnulland anOptional` and the caller of the getter knows what to expect.
Also, the name is annotated with @NotEmpty in ItemDescription. I think null is not a valid value - is it?
replies.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: ItemDescription is misused as template. And perhaps you are right: there could exist items without a name (not without identifier, however).
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: I have updated the interface and added @nullable annotations
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText: Is there any ComponentDescription that will not have a name, description and owner when the object is constructed? We are working towards more inmutability in objects, I would not invite to use the setters through the interface and rather deprecate as much setters as possible ;)
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: Yes, it is very likely that these values become available later during processing only. I would leave the input DTOs (all what extends from ComponentDescription) as mutable as possible.
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: Okay
replies.author: mfbieber

timeline.bodyText:
This is cool 😻
Shouldn't the description though be something like "Loads the open issues, open pull requests, the readme and the repositories description"?
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText:
There is no test for this, is there? Also I didn't find one for the JsonCompositeHealth. Why not addind directly a test for this new functionality? The test should be rather simple now.
I started adding jacoco with #329 and from what I saw, we can really improve on test code coverage!
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: It's tested indirectly in SpringBootHealthHandlerTest. Although you're right, I am not very motivated to invest my time in an JsonParser/TreeNode/bla etc. deep dive.
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.message: [#97] name,description can be null in ComponentDescription
